description: This introduction to “Iconic Brand Marketing” will give you a 5-Step Marketing Framework that creates sustainable growth and crazy-loyal customers even with limited resources. This hands-on workshop will show you how to pull together the best practices in marketing strategy along with some unconventional thinking to build a tribe of loyal customers who willingly refer your brand to others and make business growth FUN.
descriptionMD: This introduction to “Iconic Brand Marketing” will give you a 5-Step Marketing Framework that creates sustainable growth and crazy-loyal customers even with limited resources. This hands-on workshop will show you how to pull together the best practices in marketing strategy along with some unconventional thinking to build a tribe of loyal customers who willingly refer your brand to others and make business growth FUN.
name: The Five Unconventional Pillars of Effective Marketing
subtitle: The Five Unconventional Pillars of Effective Marketing

episodes.description: Description: This introduction to “Iconic Brand Marketing” will give you a 5-Step Marketing Framework that creates sustainable growth and crazy-loyal customers even with limited resources. This hands-on workshop will show you how to pull together the best practices in marketing strategy along with some unconventional thinking to build a tribe of loyal customers who willingly refer your brand to others and make business growth FUN.
episodes.title: Episode 1
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.231
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.231 --> 00:00:08.720
Hello everyone, I'm Kate Byars.

3
00:00:08.720 --> 00:00:13.536
What I'd like to share with you today is
something I call the iconic marketing

4
00:00:13.536 --> 00:00:14.140
method.

5
00:00:14.140 --> 00:00:17.743
We wanna talk about five unconventional
pillars of effective marketing,

6
00:00:17.743 --> 00:00:21.515
and I wanna challenge everyone in the room
to think about marketing a little bit

7
00:00:21.515 --> 00:00:22.273
differently.

8
00:00:22.273 --> 00:00:23.229
[COUGH] Typically,

9
00:00:23.229 --> 00:00:26.764
when we think about marketing we
think about the product mix, right?

10
00:00:26.764 --> 00:00:28.500
We have to have a product.

11
00:00:28.500 --> 00:00:32.559
We have to have a place to
sell our product or service.

12
00:00:32.559 --> 00:00:34.672
We also need to promote it in some way.

13
00:00:34.672 --> 00:00:38.014
We have to create awareness
around what we're doing.

14
00:00:38.014 --> 00:00:41.086
And finally, we need to have a price.

15
00:00:41.086 --> 00:00:44.653
The one place where everyone gets
really caught up in marketing, usually,

16
00:00:44.653 --> 00:00:46.100
is in the promotion piece, and

17
00:00:46.100 --> 00:00:49.576
that's a little bit of what I'm hearing
in some of your questions today.

18
00:00:49.576 --> 00:00:50.415
How do I promote it?

19
00:00:50.415 --> 00:00:54.101
How do I know that money I'm spending
on my marketing is gonna be effective?

20
00:00:54.101 --> 00:00:55.029
Should I be on LinkedIn?

21
00:00:55.029 --> 00:00:56.301
Should I be on Facebook?

22
00:00:56.301 --> 00:00:59.218
How do I use social, inbound,
outbound, traditional?

23
00:00:59.218 --> 00:01:03.391
It is just this word cloud of tons of
techniques, but that's all they are.

24
00:01:03.391 --> 00:01:08.839
Those are techniques, and those we can
narrow down and make those effective.

25
00:01:08.839 --> 00:01:12.805
The other thing we'll see companies
do sometimes is when we get stuck and

26
00:01:12.805 --> 00:01:15.146
we're not seeing the growth we wanna see,

27
00:01:15.146 --> 00:01:17.765
we start to play around
with the marketing mix.

28
00:01:17.765 --> 00:01:19.336
Maybe we need a higher-level product.

29
00:01:19.336 --> 00:01:22.412
Maybe we need a more inexpensive product.

30
00:01:22.412 --> 00:01:23.315
Maybe I should be online.

31
00:01:23.315 --> 00:01:24.194
Maybe I should be inline.

32
00:01:24.194 --> 00:01:25.621
Should I go international?

33
00:01:25.621 --> 00:01:30.561
We start messing around with the product
mix a lot of times a little bit too

34
00:01:30.561 --> 00:01:33.892
soon before we get a really
good foundation set.

35
00:01:33.892 --> 00:01:37.238
So what I wanna introduce to
you today is that foundation.

36
00:01:37.238 --> 00:01:40.372
I call it the Iconic Brand Foundation.

37
00:01:40.372 --> 00:01:42.225
So, what does this mean?

38
00:01:42.225 --> 00:01:45.661
Well, first of all, it means that
we're starting with iconic intent.

39
00:01:46.860 --> 00:01:49.813
So let me tell you a little bit
of a story on my background and

40
00:01:49.813 --> 00:01:51.032
how I discovered this.

41
00:01:51.032 --> 00:01:53.749
I started my career in advertising,
and I worked for

42
00:01:53.749 --> 00:01:57.891
several different large advertising
agencies on brands that were really big,

43
00:01:57.891 --> 00:02:01.134
like Quaker State Motor Oil,
or Pepsi, huge global brands.

44
00:02:01.134 --> 00:02:04.166
And I also had the opportunity to work for
smaller brands.

45
00:02:04.166 --> 00:02:05.231
At the time, I was in Texas.

46
00:02:05.231 --> 00:02:06.756
They were regional, Mrs.

47
00:02:06.756 --> 00:02:11.740
Baird's bread, Imperial sugar, McIlhenny
Tabasco Sauce, family owned companies.

48
00:02:11.740 --> 00:02:16.385
And we had a lot of fun in our ad agency
putting together these amazing strategies

49
00:02:16.385 --> 00:02:18.406
and these incredible campaigns.

50
00:02:18.406 --> 00:02:21.819
And we'd launch them, and the clients
would be happy cuz sales would go up.

51
00:02:21.819 --> 00:02:23.747
Yay, everybody's happy, right?

52
00:02:23.747 --> 00:02:26.597
And then, the next year, we would do
another incredible strategy session.

53
00:02:26.597 --> 00:02:29.963
We do more amazing advertising campaigns,
and

54
00:02:29.963 --> 00:02:33.759
we'd launch them, and meh,
not much would happen.

55
00:02:33.759 --> 00:02:38.280
And there seemed to be this constant
up and down with this advertising.

56
00:02:38.280 --> 00:02:41.179
And what I noticed is that, if you're
a company like Pepsi or Quaker State,

57
00:02:41.179 --> 00:02:43.102
you can throw more money at this problem,
right?

58
00:02:43.102 --> 00:02:46.579
And you can solve that problem to get
your sales to where you need them to be.

59
00:02:46.579 --> 00:02:48.671
If you're a smaller company like a Mrs.

60
00:02:48.671 --> 00:02:52.071
Baird's Bread that I was working with,
that was it for the year.

61
00:02:52.071 --> 00:02:53.958
There was no more money to spend.

62
00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.049
And I thought, wow, that's really a shame.

63
00:02:56.049 --> 00:02:57.817
There's gotta be a way to figure this out.

64
00:02:57.817 --> 00:02:58.980
There's gotta be a better way.

65
00:02:59.980 --> 00:03:03.080
Now, if anyone's ever worked in ad agency
business before, you know that you're

66
00:03:03.080 --> 00:03:06.640
probably working 16-hour days, and
you have really crazy deadlines.

67
00:03:06.640 --> 00:03:10.810
And after four years of that, I was like,
okay, maybe there's another way to work

68
00:03:10.810 --> 00:03:14.790
where I'm not working that long, and
also where I can be more effective.

69
00:03:14.790 --> 00:03:17.988
So I went to work for
this lady, Mary Kay Ash, and

70
00:03:17.988 --> 00:03:23.465
I started working inside the company as
a corporate marketer in her organization.

71
00:03:23.465 --> 00:03:25.048
Now I took with me, to Mary Kay,

72
00:03:25.048 --> 00:03:27.930
all of that frenetic energy
that you have in advertising.

73
00:03:27.930 --> 00:03:31.454
Deadlines, client demands,
I need to go, go, go.

74
00:03:31.454 --> 00:03:35.301
And about there weeks into my
brand new job at Mary Kay,

75
00:03:35.301 --> 00:03:39.829
I had been hired to be part of
a small team of functional experts.

76
00:03:39.829 --> 00:03:41.462
My functional expertise was marketing.

77
00:03:41.462 --> 00:03:45.330
I had someone else on the team who was
in finance, someone else in operations.

78
00:03:45.330 --> 00:03:48.860
And we were gonna go to Mary Kay's
international subsidiaries and

79
00:03:48.860 --> 00:03:50.377
help them grow their sales.

80
00:03:50.377 --> 00:03:54.870
At that time, Mary Kay's international had
really grown through that sort of cocktail

81
00:03:54.870 --> 00:03:58.100
napkin syndrome, where somebody says,
I know a guy in Spain.

82
00:03:58.100 --> 00:03:59.589
All right, send him some product.

83
00:03:59.589 --> 00:04:01.002
Let's see what can happen.

84
00:04:01.002 --> 00:04:04.001
And obviously, that's not a very
effective way to grow your company.

85
00:04:04.001 --> 00:04:06.227
So our team was charged for going over,

86
00:04:06.227 --> 00:04:09.680
working with the people who
were the local market experts.

87
00:04:09.680 --> 00:04:12.185
They knew their business
really well on the ground, and

88
00:04:12.185 --> 00:04:14.116
we had that functional expertise to help.

89
00:04:14.116 --> 00:04:17.669
Anyways, three weeks in, I walk in
the lobby, and here's what I see.

90
00:04:17.669 --> 00:04:19.239
Beautiful pink and black balloons.

91
00:04:19.239 --> 00:04:20.390
We're having a party, nice.

92
00:04:21.550 --> 00:04:24.920
I go in the elevator up to my office,
and there's a sign,

93
00:04:24.920 --> 00:04:28.490
10 AM, Mary Kay's birthday,
please join us in the atrium.

94
00:04:28.490 --> 00:04:33.060
Okay, that's cool, because in advertising
you don't stop to have birthday cake

95
00:04:33.060 --> 00:04:35.330
until midnight, when you've
already missed lunch and dinner.

96
00:04:35.330 --> 00:04:37.040
So the last thing I was
gonna do was come down and

97
00:04:37.040 --> 00:04:38.630
miss my 10 o'clock meeting
that I had called.

98
00:04:39.885 --> 00:04:43.394
10 o'clock,
I go to my meeting in the conference room.

99
00:04:43.394 --> 00:04:46.283
10:02, hm, no one shows up.

100
00:04:46.283 --> 00:04:48.451
10:05, what kind people
work at this company?

101
00:04:48.451 --> 00:04:50.886
Don't they show up for
their meetings on time?

102
00:04:50.886 --> 00:04:52.853
Nobody showed up for my meeting.

103
00:04:52.853 --> 00:04:53.861
I was incensed.

104
00:04:53.861 --> 00:04:57.555
And so I walked out to
the little glass banister there,

105
00:04:57.555 --> 00:05:01.265
and I looked down into the atrium,
and look what I saw.

106
00:05:01.265 --> 00:05:05.063
1,500 of my colleagues were
jammed into this atrium

107
00:05:05.063 --> 00:05:08.790
along with a whole slew of
Mary Kay Beauty Consultants.

108
00:05:09.790 --> 00:05:11.890
I had to get down there and
see what was going on.

109
00:05:11.890 --> 00:05:15.518
Something was different cuz
this was just birthday cake.

110
00:05:15.518 --> 00:05:20.399
As I stepped out of the elevator, and
I was shoulder to shoulder with all of

111
00:05:20.399 --> 00:05:24.809
these people [COUGH], Mary Kay Ash
stepped down onto a balcony, and

112
00:05:24.809 --> 00:05:27.840
literally everyone in
the room fell silent.

113
00:05:27.840 --> 00:05:32.615
And when Mary Kay Ash started to speak,
I will never forget this moment,

114
00:05:32.615 --> 00:05:35.446
cuz it taught me such an important lesson.

115
00:05:35.446 --> 00:05:38.504
She did not come out in the balcony and
say, hey everyone, thanks for

116
00:05:38.504 --> 00:05:40.055
the coming for the birthday cake.

117
00:05:40.055 --> 00:05:42.208
I really appreciate you being here.

118
00:05:42.208 --> 00:05:45.660
Thank you for helping make this
company grow to a billion dollars.

119
00:05:45.660 --> 00:05:47.207
We wouldn't have done it without you.

120
00:05:47.207 --> 00:05:49.764
Which would have been a very
nice thing to say, right?

121
00:05:49.764 --> 00:05:53.121
A lot of us as leaders might
make a speech like that.

122
00:05:53.121 --> 00:05:56.041
Instead, Mary Kay came out in
that balcony and she said, and

123
00:05:56.041 --> 00:05:59.323
I swear she was looking just at me,
and everyone else felt that way.

124
00:05:59.323 --> 00:06:05.350
She goes, I believe in you, and
I believe in you, and I believe in you.

125
00:06:05.350 --> 00:06:07.870
And you have the power to make
your dreams come true, and

126
00:06:07.870 --> 00:06:12.060
I know it cuz I've seen you do it before,
and I'm here, and I'm gonna help you.

127
00:06:12.060 --> 00:06:15.430
And whatever it is that you dream about
in life, we're gonna make that come true.

128
00:06:16.810 --> 00:06:18.849
And it was amazing.

129
00:06:18.849 --> 00:06:20.106
She did not talk about her.

130
00:06:20.106 --> 00:06:21.920
She did not talk about her company.

131
00:06:21.920 --> 00:06:23.259
She talked about me.

132
00:06:23.259 --> 00:06:27.192
And I thought, man if we could bottle
that, and we could take that overseas,

133
00:06:27.192 --> 00:06:29.000
that's what we need to be doing.

134
00:06:29.000 --> 00:06:31.398
And that's what I began
to learn at Mary Kay.

135
00:06:31.398 --> 00:06:36.660
Because Mary Kay started her
company with a piece of paper.

136
00:06:36.660 --> 00:06:41.404
And her ambition was not to
create a global cosmetic company.

137
00:06:41.404 --> 00:06:45.949
Her ambition was to enrich the lives of
women, and that's what she wanted to do.

138
00:06:45.949 --> 00:06:51.192
Because Mary Kay knew, as a single mother,
as a working mom, how hard it was,

139
00:06:51.192 --> 00:06:55.887
how few opportunities women had
back in the 1950s and 1960s.

140
00:06:55.887 --> 00:06:59.840
So she didn't start her company to
become a billion dollar company.

141
00:06:59.840 --> 00:07:02.852
She started her company to
enrich the lives of women, and

142
00:07:02.852 --> 00:07:05.005
that is their mission statement today.

143
00:07:05.005 --> 00:07:10.594
So we took that mission statement, and
we took what I was learning at Mary Kay,

144
00:07:10.594 --> 00:07:14.673
this Iconic Brand Concept,
overseas, and guess what?

145
00:07:14.673 --> 00:07:18.600
We grew a lot of international business,
and we did so profitably.

146
00:07:18.600 --> 00:07:21.223
Profits went up 3% to
10% across the board.

147
00:07:21.223 --> 00:07:24.745
That's cash to your bottom line that
you can use to grow your business.

148
00:07:24.745 --> 00:07:25.360
That's fun.

149
00:07:26.940 --> 00:07:29.134
Okay, what does it mean to be iconic?

150
00:07:29.134 --> 00:07:33.635
Usually, when I start talking about
iconic, people are like, Kate, Starbucks,

151
00:07:33.635 --> 00:07:35.499
Apple, UPS, huge, huge brands.

152
00:07:35.499 --> 00:07:36.451
I'm not a big brand.

153
00:07:36.451 --> 00:07:39.696
I don't have that money
to buy being iconic.

154
00:07:39.696 --> 00:07:41.016
You don't have to buy being iconic.

155
00:07:41.016 --> 00:07:45.428
Iconic just means that your brand is
identified as having aspects that

156
00:07:45.428 --> 00:07:48.740
contribute to the customer's
self-expression.

157
00:07:48.740 --> 00:07:54.060
Just like Mary Kay spoke to me that day on
that balcony, that's what these brands do.

158
00:07:54.060 --> 00:07:56.766
Their message is never about them.

159
00:07:56.766 --> 00:08:00.284
Their message is about the consumer,
and that is why they're iconic and

160
00:08:00.284 --> 00:08:03.110
that is why they have such
strong brand allegiance.

161
00:08:03.110 --> 00:08:07.160
They make lifetime customers,
they have very high retention rate, and

162
00:08:07.160 --> 00:08:09.810
that is a really profitable
way to run your business.

163
00:08:09.810 --> 00:08:12.230
We want customers who
give us word of mouth.

164
00:08:12.230 --> 00:08:14.755
We want customers who
come back repeatedly, and

165
00:08:14.755 --> 00:08:16.487
we want customers referring us.

166
00:08:16.487 --> 00:08:19.260
That's all these iconic brands have.

167
00:08:19.260 --> 00:08:22.380
So Starbucks, great example.

168
00:08:22.380 --> 00:08:25.852
Starbucks doesn't necessarily
have a great cup of coffee.

169
00:08:25.852 --> 00:08:28.135
A lot of people would argue that, right?

170
00:08:28.135 --> 00:08:32.160
And a lot of people would say its
overpriced, but why do we go to Starbucks?

171
00:08:32.160 --> 00:08:33.981
Because they set out to
have a great cup of coffee?

172
00:08:33.981 --> 00:08:36.417
No, Starbucks set out to be a third place,

173
00:08:36.417 --> 00:08:39.870
cuz Howard Schultz knew when
he was traveling around Italy,

174
00:08:39.870 --> 00:08:44.010
he saw all these Italians communing
in the middle of the day.

175
00:08:44.010 --> 00:08:47.865
And they were at these coffee shops and
these bistros and they were enjoying

176
00:08:47.865 --> 00:08:51.790
the camaraderie and he said we need that,
we need that in our country.

177
00:08:51.790 --> 00:08:54.470
Because we have become so
busy running and running and running,

178
00:08:54.470 --> 00:08:58.160
we don't have that third place to stop
in the middle of our busy day and

179
00:08:58.160 --> 00:08:59.830
isn't that what he's given us?

180
00:08:59.830 --> 00:09:02.200
That's what it is, so
we identify with that.

181
00:09:02.200 --> 00:09:03.740
It's not about the great cup of coffee.

182
00:09:05.410 --> 00:09:08.250
That sounds great, Kate,
let's all go be an iconic brand.

183
00:09:08.250 --> 00:09:10.689
Really what are the advantages?

184
00:09:10.689 --> 00:09:14.698
First of all, you're gonna enjoy
a higher return on investment for

185
00:09:14.698 --> 00:09:17.525
every marketing dollar you spend,
all right?

186
00:09:17.525 --> 00:09:20.700
That's nice because we want
our marketing to be effective.

187
00:09:20.700 --> 00:09:21.940
What's effective marketing?

188
00:09:21.940 --> 00:09:23.910
Marketing that works.

189
00:09:23.910 --> 00:09:27.860
You're also going to underspend on
advertising versus the competition.

190
00:09:27.860 --> 00:09:30.050
Who do you think spends
more on advertising?

191
00:09:30.050 --> 00:09:31.830
Apple, Microsoft, or Dell?

192
00:09:34.890 --> 00:09:35.680
Dell?

193
00:09:35.680 --> 00:09:36.810
Dell first, yeah.

194
00:09:36.810 --> 00:09:37.310
Who's second?

195
00:09:38.960 --> 00:09:43.160
Microsoft and then Apple,
Apple's an iconic brand.

196
00:09:43.160 --> 00:09:45.120
How many of us are wearing a Dell watch?

197
00:09:46.760 --> 00:09:47.820
Would you buy a Dell watch?

198
00:09:47.820 --> 00:09:49.580
No, Dell's a computer company,
why would I do that?

199
00:09:49.580 --> 00:09:53.080
Wait, Apple's a computer company,
we buy Apple watches.

200
00:09:53.080 --> 00:09:54.360
Do you see the difference?

201
00:09:54.360 --> 00:09:58.814
When you're an iconic brand and
when you have that customer enraptured and

202
00:09:58.814 --> 00:10:03.845
you're speaking for the customer, Apple
could make toasters and we would by them.

203
00:10:03.845 --> 00:10:07.845
And we be okay with that wouldn't we,
it might be a pretty cool toaster too.

204
00:10:07.845 --> 00:10:10.966
You're gonna get wildly loyal
customers who will become word of

205
00:10:10.966 --> 00:10:12.620
mouth referral machines.

206
00:10:12.620 --> 00:10:16.150
Our biggest problem at Mary Kay was not
bringing more customers in the door,

207
00:10:16.150 --> 00:10:17.744
it was serving the customers we had.

208
00:10:18.820 --> 00:10:20.410
That's a great problem.

209
00:10:20.410 --> 00:10:23.620
The other thing that is a phenomenal
advantage is you get a united

210
00:10:23.620 --> 00:10:26.770
internal culture that
attracts like-minded people.

211
00:10:26.770 --> 00:10:28.470
We don't have to motivate our team.

212
00:10:28.470 --> 00:10:31.040
We're not spending all this time going
how do I get my team to work harder?

213
00:10:31.040 --> 00:10:32.580
How do I get my team to show up?

214
00:10:32.580 --> 00:10:34.630
How do I get my team
to think of new ideas?

215
00:10:34.630 --> 00:10:39.810
They're excited to come to work everyday
because they believe what you believe and

216
00:10:39.810 --> 00:10:42.540
company resources are gonna
go towards serving loyalty.

217
00:10:42.540 --> 00:10:46.430
Like I said at Mary Kay, it's the most
wonderful thing for me to see is when you

218
00:10:46.430 --> 00:10:51.650
go from chasing sales to serving
customers who are willingly there.

219
00:10:51.650 --> 00:10:56.090
It's a huge pivot, it's an exciting pivot
and it's a much more profitable pivot to

220
00:10:56.090 --> 00:10:58.490
have because when customers
are excited about you and

221
00:10:58.490 --> 00:11:01.570
they identify with you, they're
already out there talking about you.

222
00:11:01.570 --> 00:11:02.760
We're gonna see some of those today.

223
00:11:04.060 --> 00:11:09.473
And finally, it's just more fun,
